column1: Letter from Thomas Chaney to his father, 1875 April 25
column17: Thomas writes to his father from Louisville (Ky.) about his travel and plans to travel, including a trip home.

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his father, 1882 December 21
column10: Cottonseed oil mills--Texas--Houston.; Cottonseed oil mills--Texas--Palestine.
column17: Thomas writes to his father from Palestine (Tex.) about demands on his time at work; getting a new cottonseed oil mill on line in Houston; the "most splendid crop year" and his hope for a "good outcome," and; finishes with his plans to spend a few days in Gaslveston (Tex.) then Christmas in New Orleans (La.)
column19: At this date, the Howard Oil Company had cottonseed mills in Palestine (Tex.), Houston (Tex.), and Dallas (Tex.)

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his sister, 1874 May 10
column17: Thomas writes to his sister from Fort Griffin (Tex.) about: his having been in transit; his condolences on the death of George; meeting a survey crew on the way to the Fort; crop failures the past three years
column19: Fort Griffin served as one in a line of western defensive forts in the north portion of West Texas from 1867 to 1881. It provided settlers protection from early Comanche and Kiowa raids

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney, 1870 August 25
column17: Thomas writes to an unknown recipient from Austin (Tex.) about: an obituary of an unnamed acquaintance from a New London (Conn.) newspaper; the reassignment of Captain Correll to the Indian frontier; an increase in Indian raids on settlers to within eighteen miles of Austin; settler retribution including scalping of Indians
column19: This letter may be missing a page.

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his parents, 1868 July 31
column17: Thomas writes to his parents from Austin (Tex.) about: his current health and well being; the organization of Texas into the Reconstruction District 5; his plans to leave "government employ" soon; political problems related to Reconstruction; the unsettled and unsafe nature of things in "the northern counties," and; closes with a comment to his father recognizing his father's opposition to "women's rights."

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his mother, 1868 May 25
column17: Thomas writes to his mother about: having just arrived at Fort Concho; his good health, and; killing his first buffalo

column1: San Antonio Agenda, 1868 May 13
column10: United States. Army. Department of Texas; Wagon trains--Texas.
column11: Boerne (Tex.); Cibolo Creek (Karnes County-Kendall County, Tex.); Guadalupe Mountains (N.M. and Tex.); Fredericksburg (Tex.); Pedernales River (Tex.); Guadalupe River (Tex.); Leon Springs (Tex.)
column17: Thomas describes three days accompanying a United States Army Quartermaster wagon train from San Antonio (Tex.) to a point four miles from Fredericksburg (Tex.)

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his brother, 1873 May 27
column17: Thomas writes to his brother about the Tonkawa Indians serving as guides and troops at Fort Griffin (Tex.)

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his mother, 1868 March 8
column10: Housing--Texas--Austin.; Cash transactions--Texas--Austin.; Austin (Tex.)--Social conditions--19th century.
column17: Thomas writes to his mother relating his current situation in Austin (Tex.)

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his father, 1867 January 4
column17: Thomas writes to his father relating his current situation in Brownsville (Tex.) mentioning a "flying visit" from Generals Sherman, Sheridan, and Griffin related to troops moving into Mexico.

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his mother, 1866 October 2
column17: Thomas writes to his mother relating his current situation in Brownsville (Tex.) mentioning the use of gold and silver rather than "greenbacks" as currency

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his mother, 1863 June 7
column17: Thomas writes to his mother relating his current situation in Alexandria (Va.) mentioning preparations to protect their position from a cavalry attack.

column1: Letter from Tom Chaney to his father, circa 1875
column17: Thomas writes to his father relating his current situation in Oskaloosa (Iowa) mentioning a trip into the local prairielands

column1: Plantation Description, 1893 December 28
column17: This is a typewritten copy of a letter from Chaney, inferred from the content of the letter, to an unknown recipient describing a plantation in which he is a one-third owner and on which one partner lives.
column19: Typewritten and stapled; may be part of an outgoing letterbook

column1: Homestead Plantation Map, 1889
column17: This is a map created from a survey by Swart & Waller, Civil Engineers. The map includes hand-written notes in red ink including the year 1894, showing what various parts of the acreage are used for, and what stage that use is in.

column1: Thomas R. Chaney Papers, 1863-1916
column17: Thomas R. Chaney (1841-1914), a Union Army veteran from Connecticut, became involved in the cottonseed oil business in the 1870s, establishing the first mills in Texas and founding the Howard Oil Company in Houston.  In 1893, he bought Homestead Plantation in St. James Parish, Louisiana, and ventured into the sugar business.  The papers consist primarily of business correspondence.
column19: Colonel Thomas R. Chaney (1841-1914) was born in Connecticut and served in the Union Army during the Civil War.  He worked for the US government afterward, and in the 1870s he became involved in the cottonseed oil business, establishing the first mills in Texas and founding the Howard Oil Company in Houston.  In 1893, he bought Homestead Plantation in St. James Parish, Louisiana, and ventured into the sugar business.  Chaney died in New Orleans on March 25, 1914.  The papers consist primarily of business correspondence.
